perturbation.original_text: This Walabot-HOME Reseller Agreement ("Agreement") is made and entered into as of this 31 day of July 2019 ("Effective Date") by and between Vayyar Imaging Ltd., having its principal place of business at 3 Avraham Giron St., POB. 325, Yehud 5621717, Israel ("Supplier"), and Inde Living Holdings, Inc., having its principal place of business at 1462 Rudder Lane, Knoxville, TN 37919 ("Reseller"). Vayyar and Reseller shall be referred to individually as "Party" and collectively as "Parties".
perturbation.changed_text: This Walabot-HOME Reseller Agreement ("Agreement") is made and entered into as of this 31 day of July 2019 ("Effective Date") by and between Vayyar Imaging Ltd., having its principal place of business at 3 Avraham Giron St., POB. 325, Yehud 5621717, Israel ("Vendor"), and Inde Living Holdings, Inc., having its principal place of business at 1462 Rudder Lane, Knoxville, TN 37919 ("Reseller"). Vayyar and Reseller shall be referred to individually as "Party" and collectively as "Parties".
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Supplier' is changed to 'Vendor' in the opening paragraph without defining if they are the same entity. This creates confusion because throughout the document, both terms are used, creating uncertainty about which entity is responsible for specific obligations. This is a form of misaligned terminology.

perturbation.original_text: Supplier shall retain all its rights and title to and ownership of all intellectual property rights in the Products including, inter alia, all documentation, enhancements, improvements or other modifications made thereof (including those modifications made in connection with Section 3.1 above), and except as expressly provided in this Agreement, Reseller shall have no right, title, or interest in any intellectual property rights in the Products. Nothing in this Section shall limit the rights of the Reseller in or to any modifications made to the Software in accordance with Section 2.3.
perturbation.changed_text: Vendor shall retain all its rights and title to and ownership of all intellectual property rights in the Products including, inter alia, all documentation, enhancements, improvements or other modifications made thereof (including those modifications made in connection with Section 3.1 above), and except as expressly provided in this Agreement, Reseller shall have no right, title, or interest in any intellectual property rights in the Products. Nothing in this Section shall limit the rights of the Reseller in or to any modifications made to the Software in accordance with Section 2.3.
perturbation.explanation: Following the change in the opening paragraph, 'Supplier' has been changed to 'Vendor' in this section too. Now, there may be confusion when other sections refer to the 'Supplier' specifically, since that definition has been changed here. This ambiguity complicates the interpretation of IP ownership.

perturbation.original_text: Reseller shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Supplier and its employees, officers, directors, suppliers, and successors from and against any third-party claim, suit, proceeding, damages, losses and/or liability arising from or related to (i) Reseller's breach of any provision of this Agreement; and/or (ii) Reseller's interaction and/or relationship with any Customer and/or End User or other third party.
perturbation.changed_text: Reseller shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Vendor and its employees, officers, directors, suppliers, and successors from and against any third-party claim, suit, proceeding, damages, losses and/or liability arising from or related to (i) Reseller's breach of any provision of this Agreement; and/or (ii) Reseller's interaction and/or relationship with any Customer and/or End User or other third party.
perturbation.explanation: Following the change in the opening paragraph, 'Supplier' has been changed to 'Vendor' in this section too. The contract lacks clarity on whether Vendor and Supplier are the same entity. As a result, the indemnification clause becomes vague. It creates a situation where it is unclear if Reseller is obliged to indemnify both Vendor and Supplier. Is it for one or the other? This ambiguity causes uncertainty in the legal agreement, because it becomes uncertain who can be defended by the indemnification clause.
